fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12303].
  {panel}

Changing a workflow takes too long (16h) and other processes can interfer (automatic backup). 
Because of the interferance the new workflow wasn't activated and most of the issues were converted to the new workflow (nobody could change these issues to resolved, closed, ...) I'm told that you need to redo the workflow change until all issues are converted (but if this takes 16 h everytime then it's not worth the trouble). So for everybodies sake I had to restore a backup to get everything going again.

It seems the workflow activation needs a workover to improve its speed and to ensure that nothing can interfere while it's running. 
It seems there's a missing indirection because every issue has to be changed when the workflow changes.
The workflow only consists of a little amount of steps. If you put something between the issue and the workflow then you should be able to change it in a few seconds and see problems when there are missing steps that can't convert. Normally you add stuff to a workflow so there shouldn't be a need to change the issue because all the steps that where in the previous workflow are also in the new workflow

Also there is nothing in the log or on the screen that gives you an indication what's going on or wrong or if it succeeded, ...

Documentation for the prof. edition only states how to activate a workflow (It wasn't hard to adjust but is this really all, no warnings that it takes allmost a day, that other processes will interfer)
fields.summary: Workflow needs workover
Need to HTML encode in order to prevent UI breaking
Add Filters Created and Issues Watched to User Profile
Make notification e-mails use issue's assignee's e-mail address as the FROM address
Percentage custom field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12270].
  {panel}

Every now and then people report performance problems, which after much effort, are traced down to a very slow filesystem (eg. NFS or virus checker), slow CPU (eg. old Sun servers running 16x 500Mhz CPUs) or slow network connection (database running remotely).

We should write some functions to profile these aspects, and print the milliseconds taken on the System Info page:

 - Exercise Lucene (create, populate, select from a test lucene index) to test the disk the index is on.
 - Run a few hundred SELECTs and INSERTs on the database to test its speed.
 - Sort a large array to test the CPU speed.
fields.summary: Print disk and CPU profiling stats on System Info page
Strip trailing whitespace from email address (and username) on entry

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12264].
  {panel}

It would be usefull to me,  to have possibility to create a custom field type user as a drop down list.
Popup picker is not ergonomical and shows all system useres and need special permission.

I would like to show only 'project users' and don't need any specially permission.

Maybe it is possible to create it as a plugin or someting else?

Best regards
Pawel.
fields.summary: Custom Field Type user (drop down list)
Subscribe/schedule a report to run and email the results

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12248].
  {panel}

It would be neat if issue links:

1. Could do a bulk change in the context of browsing the parent issue. I realize there is a custom script that allows child issues to take on the status of the parent, but sometimes we want to change them by hand to a different status. Or maybe only change some of them at one time.

2. In the issue navigator, it would be good to have 'Links' be a sortable column.

3. When displaying the issue links of a parent, it says:

This issue <italics>links to issue...<italics>.

The italics part is taken from the link type, though the 'This issue' part seems to be canned. It would be neat if the 'This issue' part of the text was replaced by the actual issue type it's referring to. I think it's rare that anyone will have an issue that's actually called 'issue'. Folks might have bugs, enhancements, tasks, etc.


Thanks!


-Matt
fields.summary: Improvements to issue linking

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12244].
  {panel}

In our JIRA implementation editing of issues is only allowed for privileged users who don't need to justify why they're making a change.  We have a lot of fields on our edit screen and even with tabs it's a bit cluttered.  We'd like to be able to nix the comment field on the edit screen to save a bit of screen real estate and clutter.  A drop-down on the Edit for a screen to enable or disable the comment field would be nice...  it could even be combined with https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4972 to a single drop-down as follows:

Comments:

Disabled (Ability To Leave Comment Does Not Appear On Screen)
Enabled And Not Required (Comment Is Optional)
Enabled And Required (User Must Leave Comment)
fields.summary: Allow control of whether comment field will be shown on Edit and Transition screens
Remove the implementations of equals() and hashCode() methods on Remote objects of the RPC plugin
Mobile client
Last Modified notifications for RSS feeds
Cannot change index path without reindexing
Need to make Group Browser available to non-administrators

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12206].
  {panel}

In 3.7, JIRA has two links on the search results page for RSS:

RSS  ( Issues  | Comments  ) 

The problem with simply linking is that the user doesn't get a chance to specify:
 - what they want back - issues, comments - why not both?
 -  what authentication type they want (defaults to none - usually not correct - see [docs|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/navigatorviews.html#Accessing+protected+data])
 - what maximum results they want (defaults to 1000 to stop crawlers killing JIRA with huge searches - frequently unexpected)


Instead, JIRA should have an RSS feed builder, like Confluence. What to get back (issues, comments, worklogs, etc) should be checkboxes, so users can get exactly what they want, and authentication should default to BASIC, since most people's issues are protected by a permission scheme.
fields.summary: JIRA needs an RSS feed builder to specify max results, authentication etc
RemoteProjectRole as an instance of RemoteEntity?
Provide atlassian-plugin.xml DTD or XSD
automatic re-index
Allow Services to validate its own input params
SOAP is incompatible with Axis2 and Xfire

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12147].
  {panel}

Allow for JIRA to send instant messages (i.e. AIM,Jabber,Google) to 
users who have accounts and are allowed to receive notifications 
for particular events.

For instance, for each user I would be able to set up an IM account at which user with the account 
would specify their credentials. If IM Notifications are turned on (Global setting I imagine), then the issue event information is sent to the IM account. It would also have include the hyperlink to the issue so they could easily click on it and go to the issue. 

I saw the capability in Bamboo to allow IM notifications, and thought JIRA could utilize this functionality very easily.
fields.summary: Allow JIRA to send notifications via instant message.
Allow Major/Minor versions under the 'Manage Versions' section of a project.
Allow for password change enforcement
Upgrade JIRA to velocity version where concurrency issues are fixed
Word 2000 fails to render CSS for children of class specified elements
Tab level security

  {panel}

How can I search by ID field
I have to filtr bugs wchich ID are e.g ABC-111 , ABC-223, ABC-333
How can i do this


Neal Applebaum [06/Feb/07 10:56 AM] 
You need to install the JIRA Toolkit, which has a custom field type called "Multi Issue Key Searcher", which does exactly that. 



It`s not exectly, becouse ihave got thi tollkit and it`s true this field give me a way wchich i can find this  3 tasks but if i saved this filtr and conected them with
portlet -  Two Dimensional Filter Statistics this portlet show me different data

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12087].
  {panel}

h4. Improvement Requests
* Include documentation identifying which RPC modules are required and which are optional
* Include workaround steps for the problem that occured below

h4.Scenario in which this would come in handy
A developer within our company wanted to try and create an xml-rpc client into JIRA.  He then asked the JIRA administrator to enable the RPC plugin.   At the time we were using JIRA 3.6.1 Professional, and had the RPC plugin disabled.  It was decided that we would enable this plugin during an upgrade to JIRA 3.7.2 Professional.

So after upgrading to JIRA 3.7.2 Professional (with all of our data now imported), we decided to turn on _"Accepting remote API Calls"_ and enable the RPC plugin according to the instructions available at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+a+XML-RPC+Client.  Not knowing what each individual module did, we decided to _disable the admin service module_ and left everything else enabled.  Screenshot shown in instructions doesn't show this module either, so thought it would be ok.  Also thought that , if anything went wrong we could just disable the entire plugin again.  However, after restarting services the {color:red}JIRA UI is no longer available.{color}  

To get our system backup we ultimately had to restore ms sql server 2000 from a clean database.  Then when the system was up, re-import all our data (which was unfortunate, since this process is very long).  It would be nice to know what the workaround for this would be, since it seems it could be manually changed in the database.   

h4.Additional Testing
Tested the same set of steps on the absolutely clean installation of JIRA 3.7.2.  Same issue is reproduced:
# Install 3.7.2
# Enable _"Accepting remote API Calls"_ and enable the RPC plugin 
# Disable Admin Service Module and leave all other modules enabled
# Restart Jira services
# Try connecting to http://localhost<port> : {color:red} UI no longer available{color}
fields.summary: [RPC JIRA Plugin] Documentation for which RPC modules are required and which are optional

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12062].
  {panel}

There are quite a few things that should be configurable when viewing an issue navigator view.

For example, maximum number of issues to export (See discussions on JRA-8899), what columns to export, etc.

Some of these parameters would be different for each navigator view.

We should build an intermediary screen to ask the user for parameters before actually running the Navigator View as we do now.
fields.summary: Create an intermediary screen to query user for parameters for each Issue Navigator Views

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12059].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 22 April 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with JIRA.

At this time, this suggestion is not on the JIRA development roadmap. 

There is a workaround, though, that might be used for the specific use case defined in the description. It involves JIRA Importers Plugin (or JIM for short), which is available for both Cloud and Server deployments of JIRA. JIM allows for issues to be imported from CSV format (also available for regular JIRA users - not only Admins) and JIM's wizard includes a step where user select the project he/she wants the issues are to be imported into. So the workaround will be to export the desired issues into CSV file using Issue Navigator and then import them back into another project using JIM.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
[dmeyer@atlassian.com|mailto:dmeyer@atlassian.com]
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}


*Original request description:*

I'm working on rolling out JIRA to a Big 10 University in the U.S. We anticipate the potential to have hundreds or possibly thousands of projects in our installation. One of the features we are keen on being able to offer our faculty is the ability to create a series of tasks organized into milestones (versions) such as phased assignments, research projects, etc. Ideally each instructor will be able to create task collections in a "master" course template, and clone out entire filter sets (including relevant issues and versions) to a collection of other projects belonging to their students. At the beginning of the course, the instructor could bulk copy these assignments and tasks out to each participant student's personal time management project, and they'd each have a unique copy of the tasks, organized into version milestones. Right now, I envision this will involve the following:
# The ability to create a project with tasks tied to given milestones. This functionality exists in the present version of JIRA (3.7.2)
# The ability to bulk copy (clone and move) an entire project milestone, including all relevant issues, to a list of projects. This feature does not presently exist.
# The possibility to deny the ability described in item 2 above to a specific list of users on the server.

I am willing to build this custom feature myself, but will need to purchase a source license first. However, the functionality might warrant a place in the default JIRA installation.

The advantage of being able to do this in a default installation of JIRA is that it would simplify multi-project installations for all Open Source communities.

EXAMPLE: all new projects need to perform basic project set-up chores (all administrivia you need to do to start an Open Source project, for example: 
* creating username on the appropriate servers, 
* setting up your ssh public keys, 
* mailing list tasks, 
* web site, 
* source repository publication, 
* adding developers and managing permissions, 
* producing unit tests, 
* documentation, 
* first release

All of these common tasks could be grouped into a "Getting Started" milestone that server admins could clone out to all new projects. We used to run into this problem at the CodeHaus all the time. The Apache software foundation also has a long list of things that all new projects must complete in order to become an official TLD. These tasks should be able to be auto-cloned wholesale to one or more existing projects from a master template.

I think having a case study on how to tie JIRA-based task management into the traditional academic enterprise would significantly increase the academic interest in this product. I saw some other issues out there that sort of batted this concept around, but nothing definitive or even that descriptive. I can't estimate how long this might take to implement, but welcome any suggestions or feedback from the JIRA development team.
fields.summary: Bulk Copy (clone+move) Issues to Multiple Projects

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-12055].
  {panel}

Hi
We are trying Jira to control all of activites in our software house. For this, we created a lot of kind of sub-tasks that represents our process like: analysis, software project, test project, development and so on. The problem that we are seeing is that there is no feature to filter and order some types of sub-tasks inside a task, and it´s dificult to visualize the information. In our context there are tasks that have more than 50 sub-tasks inside of lot of kinds of types. 
We suggest apply some type of filtering and ordering inside the tasks applied for sub-task associatedes.

Vinicius.
fields.summary: Filtering and ordering in subtasks table
When migrating workflows, don't prompt for mappings for unused issue types
Fix up issue key matching in plugins

fields.description:
After pasting a screenshot into the Screenshot applet and attaching it to an Issue, the captured screenshot is converted from raw bitmap to lossy JPEG.  JPEG is not an appropriate format for storing screen captures - as it is a lossy format it usually introduces slight distortion to images; it also is not very efficient (in terms of storage space) for typical screen captures.
I would highly recommend using PNG format for screen captures.  PNG is lossless (no distortion - the image looks as it should), has much better compression ratio than JPG - approx. 7x) and is completely free format.
I am attaching an example of both JPG and PNG for comparison.
fields.summary: Screenshots attached to an Issue should use PNG instead of JPG

fields.description:

The reason is the Issue Updated and Issue Commented notifications
are differents therefore we would like to be able to attach files or screenshot
when commenting an issue.

It would be better if i can be fully customizable like the Resolve Issue Screen and Workflow Screen.

--
Vinh-Thach

Hi,

I'm trying to add a custom field to capture the time lost by a project due to a given issue. It would behave as the "Original Estimate" field where I can input 1w, 1d, 1h,... I would then want to build a report againt the entire project and all // selected versions to know how much time is lost overall.

We're running Enterprise 3.7 build 184. Did I miss this in the custom field or is it not yet there?

Thanks in advance for your help,
Guillaume

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11990].
  {panel}

I would like to raise this request, either allow everyone to see new User Properties
or add permissions to them. Otherwise this feature is useless because only Administrators
can view these User Properties. 
We use Jira for customer support so we want to record extra information on customer
as ironically mentioned in Jira 3.7 release note, 
"Ever wanted to record some additional information about a user? For instance, you might want to record their phone number, location, department, cost centre, etc." 
How useful is this if only Administrators can view these new user properties ?

Secondly, possibility to configure Add User form with new User Propertiies fields, which can be required or optional.
fields.summary: Permissions on viewing of User Properties which can be add as default fields into Add User form in Jira 3.7

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11987].
  {panel}

Users who download the ZIP version on Unix, Linux or Mac cannot run JIRA due to the following startup error:

If you encounter issues starting up JIRA Standalone Edition, please see the Troubleshooting guide at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Installation+Troubleshooting+Guide 
The BASEDIR environment variable is not defined correctly 
This environment variable is needed to run this program 

The error occurs when the setclasspath.sh file isn't executable because the user used the zip distribution instead of the tar.gz.

To avoid this, we should fix our zip distribution so it sets the executable bit.
fields.summary: Executable bit not set on shell scripts in zip distribution

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11982].
  {panel}

With 3.7.x releases, it is now possible to add properties to users profiles, and that's a very cool feature. In that way, we may want to add some http links properties such as an homepage, an intranet link, or a second email... 

For example I could create new properties such as :
- Home page / http://website.com
- Personal Email / me@mymail.com

But at this time, the view property page (user profile) doesn't display an active link but just some text... 
Could this small improvement be planned to take part of a future release?

Thanks in advance,
Cheers
Pierrick
fields.summary: User properties : Rendering URL type properties
Enable update of worklog via SOAP and / or XMLRPC

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11970].
  {panel}

As a security measure we do not want to allow more than 2 concurrent logins for any Jira user.
Unfortunately, this feature is not available in JIRA 3.7.1 Enterprise. 
I will strongly recommend including this in your future release.

Please refer to support issue # JSP-9605
fields.summary: As an admin I would like to be able to set the amount of concurrent logins per user
Issue Screen => "Viewable By" - By default should display only the Project Members

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11966].
  {panel}

In a restrictive project users generally might not have the permission to assign issues to other participants,
except via workflows and only if this coincidates with a status change (this is what is required by my project,
an assignment where a status change is involved at the same time). 

Withdrawing the "assign" permission will let the assign-option disappear from the "action" menu (which is good) 
but also entails that users can no longer be picked from e.g. the Standard Workflow Screen, since this is not permitted 
to the current user. It seems to me that workflow transitions will be executed in the security context of the presently logged  
in user.

Is there an issue/solution I missed?

THX,
Klaus
fields.summary: issue assignment allowing for change of status (workflow vs. action)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11953].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When sending an email, it is always nice to be able to see who received it (by looking at the To: Cc: Bcc:)

JIRA is sending out email notifications all the time but it is not possible to see who received them. Notification schemes and workflows can change at anytime but there is no way to look back in the history of a bug to see who got notified and when.

I guess you could only see everything in context when you click on "All" because "Comments" and "Change History" both result in an email notification.

Just an example of why this would be useful - in our company, we use JIRA like an information tool. Sometimes whilst commenting on an issue, we like to "copy" a few people so that they see the comment. It would be great to have this logged so we can see who actually received a notification.

h3. Suggested Solution
Within an issue, you can see "All", "Comments", "Work Log", "Change History" and "Version Control". Would it be possible to add a new one called "Notifications"? 

h3. Workaround
Use a third-party plugin which already have this feature; [Enterprise Mail Handler for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.javahollic.jira.jemh-ui/cloud/overview]. Please refer to [Enable the Notification History Issue Tab|https://thepluginpeople.atlassian.net/wiki/display/JEMH/Enable+the+Notification+History+Issue+Tab] for more information.
fields.summary: Show notification history within an issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11951].
  {panel}

Hi,

I am not sure whether this feature has already been requested. If yes, could you point me to the appropriate documentation.

Is it possible for Jira to send automatic notification when a particular open issue has been inactive for a while... i.e. no comments, no work on the issue being done. For e.g. If the issue has been inactive for.. say 2 weeks (customisable) or so... an email notification is to be sent to the Assignee/Reporter that no activity has been occured for the past 2 weeks.

I am happy to give more details on this.

Thanks,

Vijesh
fields.summary: Issue Inactive notification
Ability to add options to a multi user/group picker
Improve the reporting functionality
Provide pre and post link hooks
DWIM date inputs
Additional Jelly CreateUser tags

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11884].
  {panel}

After implementering Project Roles in JIRA 3.7 you have unfortunately introduced a _major_ security violation.

In earlier versions of JIRA the Administer Projects permission granted a user the right to edit a project, manage components and manage versions. In 3.7 this permission also grants the user the right to _Manage Project Role Membership._

I know this is part of the idea behind introducing Project Roles. But it _must_ be possible to exclude users from this right even though they have the Administer Projects Permission. This could be done by introducing a Global Permission: "Manage Project Role Membership".

In our JIRA installation we have 12 JIRA administrators. The are the _only ones_ that are allowed to manage users and groups. We have a lot of Project Leads that are allowed to Administer Projects. They need to be able to manage components, versions and so on. We even have some _customers_ that are granted the Administer Projects permission because they run their own JIRA projects.

The problem that has been introduced is not so much, that a user with the Administer Projects permission can add a single user to a Project Role. I could live with that. The problem is, that they can also _add a group_. This means that a user by accident can add a wrong user to a project by giving them indirect access (via the group) without knowing it. The users with Administer Projects permissions have no way of knowing which users are in a given group. Only administrators can see this from the Group Browser.

Another is that the users can see the "Assign Groups to Project Role". Now the users can see all the groups in JIRA, not only the groups they are a member of. Users without the Global "Browse Users" permission (which also controls the ability to browse groups) should not be able to do this. In our JIRA installation groups represents customers. This means that some of our customers now can see the names of some of our other customers... not good...

I urge you to fix this in a 3.7.x version a soon as possible. 

Thanks.

Regards,
Lars

Edit: 2017-02-01
h5. Slightly formalised summary
As Jira administrator I want to segregate two Permission: _Administer projects_ (current Permission) and _edit Roles_ (new Permission)
* Project lead/administrator will not have ability to modify the roles (delegate permissions) but can manage their project for remaining admin functions
fields.summary: Security Violation: Manage Project Role Membership needs a Global Permission

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11864].
  {panel}

We need a URL we can use in support and discussions with customers for:

- raising a support request in the correct support project
- raising a bug/improvement request in the correct jac project

If the user is logged in, it should take them to the Create Issue screen with the correct project and issue type selected. If the user isn't logged in, there would be a introductory landing page describing how to create an account and create an issue (since that's what they're trying to do).

For the URLs, I'd suggest something like:

http://jira.atlassian.com/create/CONF

Where the parameter of the URL is the project key. It would be a bonus to include the issue type in the URL (a la quick search):

http://jira.atlassian.com/create/CONF/bug
http://jira.atlassian.com/create/CONF/improvement

Although it's punctuation soup to a user who doesn't understand URLs (and therefore not as pretty), a query parameter might make an easier implementation:

http://jira.atlassian.com/create?CONF+bug
fields.summary: Pretty URL for creating issues in a particular project
Allow defaults for custom fields to be set on a project (field configuration) basis
Allow global permssions to use roles in additon to groups
Project Broadcast Banner
Add "Assign to Role Member" workflow post-function
Ability to cut and paste a file location into a URL field
Expose managers through ComponentManager
Beat Current Powerball Record

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11807].
  {panel}

As of JIRA 3.4, JIRA has a RegexCommentHandler, which parses emails for separators from broken mail clients (contributed by a user, IIRC). People now want the ability to create *or* comment on an issue, using regular expressions.

We should either:
 -  (preferably) pull the regexp parsing capability out of RegexCommentHandler, and add its 'splitregex' parameter to CreateOrCommentHandler.
 -  create a RegexCreateOrCommentHandler
fields.summary: Add a Create or Comment regexp handler for incoming mail
Whitelist of domains in referrer/trackback for intranets

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11773].
  {panel}

Currently, we have an issue security scheme that specifies a security level of "Reporter plus support." Of course, the "Users/Groups" for this level is "Reporter" plus the group of users that comprise the support folks. This has worked really well for us.

Some of our "customers" have more than one user that submits issues, and they would like to see all the issues reported by their "company."

Rather than try to manage this with separate groups (one for each customer, I would like to try this:

We need something like a "Reporter Domain" user/group and when this is specified, security checks would work similar to the "Reporter" user. But instead of comparing the id of the current signed-on user with the id of the reporter of the issue, compare the e-mail domain of the signed-on user with the "reporterdomain" custom field (that is implemented by one of the Atlassian supplied plug-ins) in the issue.

We would like to see this as both an issue security level and as a transition condition.

Clearly the execution code change is very small. The trick is going to be getting this configurable, translated, documented, etc.

A portion of this is already implemented in that we already have the "reporterdomain" field configured. 

Of course, using e-mail for this introduces it's own set of requirements on registration. For example, there needs to be a flag in configuration to require e-mail verification. That is, it should not be possible for someone to register with an e-mail address of tom@mycompany.com and then be able to look at all issues reported by anyone at mycompany.com without at least going through mycompany's e-mail system first.
fields.summary: CLONE -Add "reporter domain" permission
Duedate system field to use datetime format instead

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11756].
  {panel}

*Example:* I create task and initially estimate it for 2 weeks. After few days I start working on that issue but 2 weeks is too long for single issue, so I divide it to multiple subtasks. If I estimate subtasks subsequently project's estimate will grow artificially because I estimate subtasks having estimated parent task. 
*End of example*

In my view after dividing task into subtasks original estimate of parent task should be 0 and should be calculated from all relevant subtasks. 
Other solution would be not to include estimations from subtasks into the project/release estimation sum. This way after logging work for subtask remaining estimation for parent task should be decremented accordingly.
fields.summary: Original estimate of parent task should be calculated
Enable Project Administrators the ability to log work on behalf of issue owners

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11733].
  {panel}

Currently the 'All' link on the *Projects* gadget uses the following filter parameters to display its results:

Project: project_name
Sorted by: Key descending

If a project however has certain issue types associated with it that are then associated with a particular custom field then the custom field will not appear in the results set after clicking on *All* because issue types are not specified in the filter.
fields.summary: 'All' link on the gadget should respect issue types associated with the Project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11699].
  {panel}

Hello,

When adding a comment to an issue, it would be great if we could specify a user instead of a group for the comment's visibility.

We are using Jira as an helpdesk system and it is often necessary to communicate passwords. If we could set the visibility of the comment to the reporter only, it will be more secure.

Thanks,
Cécile
fields.summary: Comments Visibility - Possibility to specify a user instead of a group
Issue constant icon is not displayed on the 'add subtask blocking workflow condition'

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11593].
  {panel}

Some users have multiple transitions between a single pair of statuses. That's why the change history tab should also include the transition name. For example:

Change it from:
|| Old Status ||  New Status ||
| Open | In Progress |

to:
|| Old Status || Transition ||  New Status ||
| Open | Start Progress | In Progress |

Cheers,
Terry

JIRA file upload is limited to 2 Gigabytes

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11552].
  {panel}

Hi,

When you create/configure a screen , you have the ability to rename tabs  but notto translate them.

To give you an example, i created a screen for issue creation containing 3 tabs "Summary", "Detail", "Attachment".

I would like the possibility to translate this in French for our French users but it doesnt seem possible?

This should be possible from the admin interface. At the moment our french users are presented with a mix of french and english screens and tabs, i hope this can be improved.

Thanks


Mel
fields.summary: Need Ability to Translate Tabs in Screen Configuration
SOAP to support delete version

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11506].
  {panel}

Hi

I want to generate all my project management reporting out of Jira.  In order for me to do this most effectively I need some additional attributes associated with each "Version" within a Project.

At the we have the following attributes associated with a Version:
- Version Name
- Description
- Release Date
- Schedule

I require the following additional attributes:
- Start Date (estimated start date for items within the Version)
- Owner (The owner of a particular Version.  This would be some the list of users with access to the Jira project)

If you could support a flexible way to add custom fields to Versions that would be best
fields.summary: Require additional attributes associated with Versions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11480].
  {panel}

One of important features of any workflow, task-management, project-management software is an alerter functionality. Currently, Jira supports only e-mail alerts, plus some 3-d party extensions are available, which are not convenient (some require a specific JDK and run as a stand-alone application, some support a specific browser only). All these alerters can be treated only as a temporary work-arounds for a native built-in http alerter, to be provided by Jira.

As Jira's client is a browser, the most natural and convenient way of getting alerts is on Jira's html pages. I'd suppose, that http alerter should comprise a listener (perhaps, the same one as for e-mail alerts will suite with minor changes?) and a client-side renderer of a dynamic html. The renderer must fetch a data from the listener every predefined period of time (configurable by a user) and place its statistics on top of currently opened Jira page. I mean that the div tag, which is supposed to be used for the rendering, must be placed in common header (a mean the leading bar on top of every page above Jira's menu or the Jira's menu itself; both have an empty space at the right side) for all Jira pages. The statistics of the http alerter should show how many new issues are available by priority, for example: New issues: 1/2/3/4 (8 total), where 1/2/3/4 - are number of issues in all priorities, starting with a highest priority. The text should be a link, which allows a user to open a filter showing all the new issues.

How long an issue should be treated as a "new" one and listed in the alerter statistic - this is a question. Because the http alerter should provide the same cumulative quality, which e-mail provides by means of inbox, I'd suggest, that new issues remain in the http alerter list until either they viewed in the abovementioned filter, or each one of them is opened by user (in this case issues may leave the alerter list separately). The easiest way is, of course, just to clear the alerter list every time a user clicks the alerter link. The best way is to track the newness of each issue based on whether it was actually viewed by a user or not.

I think, everyone agree, that properly placed and timely alerts will make Jira much more efficient, than the static and annoying "hit refresh yourself" approach offered now.

E-mail alerts are not convenient and involve technical overheads: they require to have and to switch to another application, they flood inbox with a lot of e-mail, which are actually not e-mails and will be deleted once a user switched back to Jira and processed corresponding issues; they lack usability overall.
fields.summary: HTTP alerter is a must

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

*also check the install docs for any references to this jar*

Add ability to edit resolution

Multiple columns sorting - set and show the order and direction of sorting for every column.

Perform issue workflow actions through JIRA XML-RPC API
add a "Project Roles" column to the Group Browser

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11384].
  {panel}

As a Project Manager I find the Version Workload Report quite useful however it suffers from some limitations:

1 - it assumes that ALL issues in the version are in the same active 'state' which in our organisation are based on a custom field. 
2 - if a 'Project' encompasses more than one project in jira multiple reports need to be run

 We use a filters to be able to list issues according to the state they are in across projects as necessary, however, the Version Workload Report doesn't allow Filters to be used to filter down the contents of the report.

Please can either the Version Workload Report pick up filters from the user's filter list as well as the versions and to create the same output, or a new report be created that results in the same output?
fields.summary: Version Workload Report - improvement or create a different report effectively a Filter Workload Report

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-11371].
  {panel}

It is very awkward to create bugs filter that specified a range of versions.
for example all the bugs that affect 3.6.3 to 3.6.5 
In other enterprise-level issue trackers its possible to filter by ranges e.g. affected>=3.6.3 and affected<=3.6.5
or similar requirement affected==3.6.X

This is a mandatory requirement for robust operation in an enterprise environment. 

Currently you need to manually add all of the versions/builds to your filters, which is very awkward as you add builds/versions.
fields.summary: It should be possible to look for a range of versions in a filter
